subject: Programming
title: The Software Crisis of 1968
description: A fast breakdown of The Software Crisis of 1968 for builders.

hook.text: In 1968, NATO declared software development was in crisis. Projects failed more often than they succeeded.

buildup.text: Hardware kept getting faster, but software projects routinely ran over budget, over time, and full of bugs.

discovery.text: The conference coined 'software engineering' â€” the idea that building software needed real discipline.

twist.text: Over fifty years later, most large software projects still struggle with the same problems.

climax.text: The crisis never ended. It evolved into a permanent challenge that spawned an entire profession.

punchline.text: The crisis that started it all never really ended.
